intro: Rosa arvensis var. erronea, commonly known as the field rose or creeping rose, is a variant of the common dog玫瑰. It is a perennial shrub characterized by its thorny stems and clusters of fragrant, pink to white flowers. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and along fences. Its leaves are compound, consisting of five to seven oval leaflets, and it produces red or pink hips in the fall. This variety is notable for its adaptability and widespread distribution across temperate regions.
